# The basis of opinion.

I have conducted the audit in accordance with the guidance issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance and the audit standards of the Audit Commission. The responsibilities I am appointed as under those standards are detailed in the section of this report, “The auditor’s responsibilities relating to the audit of the financial statements.” According to those standards, I am independent of the Group, and have fulfilling other ethical responsibilities in accordance with those standards. I believe that the audit evidence I have obtained is adequate and appropriately provides the foundation for my opinion.

# Key Audit Items

Key audit matters are, based on my professional judgment, the most significant items for the audit of the Financial statements for the annual year ended December 31, 2020. I addressed these items when auditing the financial statements as a whole and forming my opinion, and I will not provide a separate opinion on these items.

# Other information

The Financial Management Officer is responsible for other information. This information includes all data in the Financial Management Authority’s 2020 annual report, but does not include financial statements and my auditor’s report.

My feedback on the financial statements does not cover other information, and I also do not publish any attestation conclusions regarding other information sessions.

Regarding the audit of financial statements, I have a responsibility to read other information to consider whether it is significantly contradictory to the financial statements or the circumstances I have ascertained during the auditing process, or appears to present there is significant misstatements. Based on the work I have already carrying out, if I believe other information exists significant misstatements, I need to report that fact. In this aspects, I have no reports.

# The responsibility of the Audit Committee under the Finance Management employees and the Foreign Exchange Fund Consultation Committee with respect to financial statements.

The Financial management employees are responsible for preparing true and fair financial statements in accordance with the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants’ promulgated “Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards” and the guidance issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance, and apply the internal control they deem necessary to make sure the financial statements do not present there is significant misstatements resulting from fraud or error.

When preparing Financial statements, financial management employees are responsible for assessment of the Group's sustainable operating capacity, and to disclose items related to sustainable operations when circumstances require, serving as a sustainable basis for accounting.

The Audit Committee, under the Foreign Exchange Fund Consultation Committee, is responsible for supervising the Group's financial reporting process.

# The responsibility an auditor bears for the audit of financial statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable Guarantee regarding whether the aggregate financial statements are free of material misstatement due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report including my opinion. Reasonable Guarantee is a high standard of Guarantee, but it cannot ensure that an audit conducted in accordance with auditing standards will determine any material misstatement that exists. A misstatement is material if it is reasonably expected to affect the economic decisions made by users of the financial statements, either individually or in the aggregate.

In the process of conducting an audit in accordance with the audit standards of the Audit Commission, I will apply professional judgment and uphold a professional skeptical attitude. I will also:
- Identify and assess the risk of material misstatements in the financial statements due to fraud or error; design and execute audit procedures to address these risks; and obtain adequate and appropriate audit evidence as a basis for my opinion. Since fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, false statements, or overriding of internal control, the risk of not detecting material misstatements due to fraud is higher than the risk of not detecting those due to error;
- Understand internal control related to the audit in order to design appropriate audit procedures. However, this is not intended to express an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group’s internal control;
- Evaluate whether the accounting policies adopted by the Financial Management Officer are appropriate, and whether the accounting estimates made and related information disclosures are reasonable;
- Determine whether the Financial Management Officer’s practices of using the going concern basis of accounting are appropriate, and based on the audit evidence obtained, determine whether there are significant uncertainties related to events or circumstances that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern. If I believe that significant uncertainties exist, it is necessary to request users to pay special attention to the related disclosures in the financial statements in the auditor’s report. If the related disclosures are insufficient, I must issue a non-unqualified auditor’s report. My conclusion is based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the auditor’s report. However, future events or circumstances may cause the Group to be unable to continue as a going concern;
- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure, and content of the financial statements, including disclosures, and whether the financial statements fairly reflect the transactions and events; and

# 1 Main business activities

The Financial Secretary, as the Exchange Fund (Fund) Manager, delegates authority to the Financial Management Officer to manage the Fund in accordance with the provisions of the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Cap. 66). The Fund's main business is to safeguard the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate and to maintain the stability and soundness of Hong Kong's currency and financial system.

The Fund’s assets are managed through four different portfolios: the Backing Portfolio, the Investment Portfolio, the Long-term Growth Portfolio and the Strategic Asset Portfolio. In accordance with the Hong Kong Currency Board System, the assets of the Backing Portfolio are fully matched with the Monetary Base. The Investment Portfolio invests principally in the bond and equity markets of member economies of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. The Long-term Growth Portfolio holds private equity (PE) and real estate investments. The Strategic Asset Portfolio holds shares of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased by the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (Hong Kong) for strategic purposes and included in the Fund’s accounts. Preparing financial statements in accordance with Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards requires management to make judgments, estimates and assumptions, and these judgments, estimates and assumptions will affect the adoption of accounting policies and the presentation amount of assets, liabilities, income and expenditure.
